awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff (UAPB) STEM Academy
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects in the Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate program provide support to design, implement, study and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This implementation project at the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff (UAPB) seeks to build on a model that has proven successful in recruiting, retaining and graduating African-American undergraduates in STEM, to include a focus on veteran and Hispanic STEM students. Key activities are based on the existing UAPB STEM Academy Model with new evidence-based interventions to be researched and disseminated. The project is guided and informed by an on-going evaluation.

Specific objectives of the project are to: increase the enrollment, retention, and graduation rate of underrepresented minority students, including veterans in STEM disciplines; increase the number of veteran STEM scholars; increase the number of STEM students who pass Calculus I and II; increase the number of STEM scholars participating in internships; increase the number of UAPB STEM faculty participating in research and mentoring STEM scholars; and increase the number of STEM graduates who enter graduate school and receive graduate fellowships from NSF, other governmental agencies, and private foundations. The program will create support for strong student engagement through collaborative learning and research, enrichment of the mathematics curriculum and pedagogy, and campus research mentorship supplemented by summer internships. The project will assess the key components, while implementing interventions and modifications necessary to prepare the STEM scholars for the workforce and graduate school. This project can serve as a model for providing support to veteran STEM students and for purposefully recruiting and supporting Hispanic STEM students at a Historically Black University.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff is an HBCU with a Land Grant mission and the only public 4-year HBCU in Arkansas. The UAPB STEM Academy has been developed into one of the “Points of Pride” at the University and is a well-integrated set of enrichment programs designed to help meet local, state and national human resource needs in STEM areas.  Our mission has a particular purpose on increasing the pool of well-prepared underrepresented minorities in STEM majors and careers. The outcomes achieved in the funding cycle were increased enrollment, retention and graduation of the targeted population.  The various activities implemented best practices that lead to successful results in creating a STEM pipeline for underrepresented minorities obtaining STEM degrees, participating in cutting-edge research, internships (domestic and international) and permanent employment in STEM related careers. The expansion of STEM opportunities for K-20 education are vital to change the lives of many underrepresented groups for their futures.  The terms of diversity, inclusion and belonging are not just words to UAPB STEM Academy Scholars.  These are obtainable goals, with preparation, that creates the much needed transformation.  Some activities include the STEM Summer Academy, STEM Saturday Academy and the Science Fair Expo have empowered students to work, strive and persist to bachelor, masters and doctorate degrees in STEM areas.  UAPB STEM Faculty also increased their research footprint with more students conducting research on the campus to enhance the change.  The outreach and dissemination performed by the UAPB STEM Academy has exposed an entire generation of students to Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics which was previously not available to them.  Another major outcome from the project was the development, implementation and refinement of the STEM Academy Model which has been beneficial to all facets of the project and will continue to be disseminated by publications, internet, social media and conferences.  The UAPB STEM Academy continues to partner with private companies, federal, state and local agencies to offer experimental and didactic STEM knowledge to a diverse group of students to prepare them for the professional STEM workforce.The synergy created by this project has made it an integral part of the University’s Strategic Plan and continues to be supported by the University.  The STEM Building, a 29,000 ft2 facility dedicated to STEM Academy is still one of the showcase facilities of the campus, since it was opened.For more information on the NSF-funded UAPB STEM Academy, please visit  http://www.uapb.edu/administration/research_innovation_and_economic_development/stem_academy.aspx


Last Modified: 12/31/2021
Modified by: Charles R Colen

Our mission has a particular purpose on increasing the pool of well-prepared underrepresented minorities in STEM majors and careers. The outcomes achieved in the funding cycle were increased enrollment, retention and graduation of the targeted population.  The various activities implemented best practices that lead to successful results in creating a STEM pipeline for underrepresented minorities obtaining STEM degrees, participating in cutting-edge research, internships (domestic and international) and permanent employment in STEM related careers. The expansion of STEM opportunities for K-20 education are vital to change the lives of many underrepresented groups for their futures. Another major outcome from the project was the development, implementation and refinement of the STEM Academy Model which has been beneficial to all facets of the project and will continue to be disseminated by publications, internet, social media and conferences.
